courses.name: Introduction to Québec Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to various aspects of Québec literature and culture through the study of literary texts, cinema, and artistic productions, and their role in the evolution of a distinct Québec society. The course also familiarizes students with important socio-cultural and political events, which participated in the evolution of Québec society and provide a better understanding of Québec literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Québec Literature and Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). Students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to French Cultural and Literary Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a practical introduction to concepts, methods and problems of literary analysis as well as an overview of French artistic culture. Using elements of comparison from fine arts, contemporary and popular culture (including novels and movies) and a variety of emblematic works of French and Francophone literatures (among others: essays by Voltaire, Montesquieu and Simone de Beauvoir; poems by Ronsard, Hugo, Baudelaire and Césaire; excerpts from novels by George Sand, Albert Camus and Patrick Chamoiseau); its objective is to provide students with a practical introduction to the tools of literary analysis, but also to help them better read, understand and appreciate literary texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to French Cultural and Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). Students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides a general introduction to French and francophone literature of different genres and periods. Special emphasis will be placed on concepts, methods, and problems of literary analysis with the goal of helping students to improve their ability to write literary essays. Among the questions to be explored are: What are the rules and conventions of scholarly writing? How does one develop and structure arguments to ensure that a paper is well organized? How are rhetorical devices analyzed? When and how should bibliographical references be inserted?
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to French Literary Analysis
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FRE245H1 and FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

courses.name: The French Language: A Linguistic Introduction

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introduction to the structure of French language, from a linguistic perspective. Students will become acquainted with the various components of the language (sound, meaning, word formation, sentence structure) through detailed description and basic analysis of Canadian and European varieties of French. Students will also be introduced to the study of French in the context of bilingualism (second language acquisition, sociolinguistics). This course is mandatory in all specialist and major programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: The French Language: A Linguistic Introduction
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). All students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the enrolment deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability. The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to the History of the French Language

cmCourseInfo.description: A discovery of a long and fascinating history, stretching from the spoken Latin of the Gauls to the many varieties of French found today all over the world via the investigation of the social, political, and cultural causes of language change. Our focus includes topics such as medieval bilingualism, the regulation of language through the Académie française, the political use of the French language, the emergence of the Francophonie and modern Canadian French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the History of the French Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

courses.name: Introduction to the Linguistic Analysis of French

cmCourseInfo.description: An analytical study of contemporary French phonetics and phonology, morphology, syntax and semantics. This course is designed to prepare students for more advanced study of French linguistics at the 300 and 400 levels.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Linguistic Analysis of French

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The placement test www.lang.utoronto.ca/placement/french is mandatory for students who do not have the prerequisites.

courses.name: Relations between Text and Other Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Literary texts and other forms of media (photographs, cinematographic images, paintings) have been associated in a fascinating relation in hundreds of works of French literature. An exploration of this inextricable weaving together of verbal and visual experiences as it pertains to literature through the study of interdisciplinary theoretical texts focused on photography, painting, and cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Relations between Text and Other Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Literature of the 20th and 21st centuries speaks of contesting social and literary figures of authority, of challenging traditional literary structures, and of accentuating creativity and subjectivity. An exploration of the thematic and formal structures that challenge traditional forms of thinking and writing in contemporary literature from Québec and other French-speaking parts of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Quebec and French-Canadian Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Religious fervour, chivalry, romance and ribald humour, heroic deeds, marvellous adventures, and exotic travels as found in selected texts from the French Middle Ages. Readings in modern French translations with appropriate reference to the original language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval French Literature

courses.name: Laughter and Thought in French Renaissance Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the fascinating literary diversity, prose, theatre and poetry essential to the changing humanistic discourse of the French Renaissance and Baroque periods. The underscoring of important historical events - Reformation, Great Discoveries, Printing - to explain the philosophical and literary values produced by such violent times.
cmCourseInfo.title: Laughter and Thought in French Renaissance Literature

courses.name: French Literature in the Time of Revolutions and Industrialization

cmCourseInfo.description: The long 19th century (1789-1914) is characterized by change: from political upheavals to literary, scientific, and media revolutions, the spread of literacy, and the rapid development of industrialization and colonization. A study of the evolution of literature (genres, forms, movements); as influenced by these changing socio-political and economic contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Literature in the Time of Revolutions and Industrialization

cmCourseInfo.description: Characterized by experimentation and the crisis of representation, French literature of the 20th and 21st centuries has undergone numerous transformations in form, content, and generic boundaries. A study of these literary movements, trends, and transgressions in poetry, prose, and theatre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary French Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Information regarding the classroom associated with this course will be provided to students through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: The fundamentals of postcolonial theories, with emphasis on how they relate to the Francophone world. The dialogue between fiction and theory, as well as the modalities of a coherent Francophone postcolonial identity in a global world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Postcolonialism: Francophone Literatures

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Information regarding the classroom associated with this course will be provided to students through Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: Survey of the main literary genres and analysis of their features, with in-depth study of two of the genres: narrative (epic poem, novel, short narrative); lyric poetry, drama (tragedy, comedy, farce, mystery play); essay. Readings of selected texts, chosen for their representative potential and their historical relevance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literary Genres

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the phonological and phonetic systems of modern French based on actual samples of speech taken from different regional varieties and socio-economic groups.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Phonology and Phonetics

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the distribution and relationships of the syntagmatic components of contemporary French; of sentential structure, including the principles of coordination, subordination and expansion; and of major theoretical approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Syntax

cmCourseInfo.description: The relationship between language use and social factors such as socio-economic status, social context and gender of speaker. Theoretical notions are derived through the analysis of specific data, focusing on Canadian French and other varieties spoken in the Americas.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociolinguistics of French

courses.name: Quantitative Methods for the Study of French

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the foundations of quantitative research on French. Topics include differences between quantitative and qualitative analyses; hypothesis formulation; experimental design; and data collection and analysis including basic statistical methods. Phenomena investigated come from Canadian and European varieties as well as studies of second language learners.
cmCourseInfo.title: Quantitative Methods for the Study of French

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is a 3-hour course (2-hr lecture, 1-hr tutorial). Students must enroll in both the lecture and the tutorial for a total of three hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

cmCourseInfo.description: Various approaches to the notion of meaning; its functioning at all levels of representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Semantics

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced interdisciplinary research seminar devoted to specific issues of Québécois literature and culture. Focus on a literary genre, a particular subject matter, a literary movement, or based on a multidisciplinary approach to cinema, arts, and music. For more information, see https://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Quebec Literature:

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced, research-oriented seminar devoted to specific issues of French literature and culture. Focus on a literary genre, a particular subject or literary movement, or based on a multidisciplinary approach involving cinema, arts, and music. For more information, see https://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in French Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced, research-oriented seminar devoted to questions concerning the authors practice, originality, and oeuvre. Production, performance and prominence, characteristic genres, religious and philosophical thought, theoretical reflection on literature, language, and belonging as aspects of the analysis of one single authors body of writing. For more information, see https://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics: Authors

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims to ensure an understanding of Old French, to read most of the medieval texts. From a selection of texts, it explores the form of the language in various centuries and regions and provide a basis for understanding the history of the French language. This course is also listed in the offerings of the Graduate department of French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval French Language

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Bilingualism and L2 acquisition

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how adult learners acquire various aspects of French language (vocabulary, syntax and/or phonology). It also provides in-depth, practical training in methodological design and quantitative analysis culminating in students’ undertaking of individual experimental studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Bilingualism and L2 acquisition

courses.name: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics I

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced seminar on a specific aspect of French linguistics. For more information, see https://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Varies according to particular course offering; consult the French Studies Undergraduate brochure (www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate) for exact prerequisites.

courses.name: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics II

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced seminar on a specific aspect of French linguistics. For more information, see https://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Varies according to particular course offering; consult the French Studies Undergraduate brochure (www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate) for exact prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project on a linguistic, literary, or second language learning topic to be proposed by the student and supervised by a Faculty member, culminating in a major research paper. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Essay
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 300+ FRE Linguistics/Literature/Second Language Learning course. Permission of Department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Applicants must complete the Ballot for Admission and the Description of Project Form, available at https://www.french.utoronto.ca/other-courses/fre-491h492h-independent-study and return them, duly signed by their supervisor, to Alex Yeung, room 226, Odette Hall. An electronic version of the application must be forwarded to french.undergraduate@utoronto.ca The deadlines are as follows: - before the end of the first week of classes in September for F and Y courses; - before the end of the first week of classes in January for S courses; - before the end of April for all summer courses.

Delivery Instructions

If approved, supervisor will inform student of delivery method.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project on a linguistic, literary, or second language learning topic to be proposed by the student and supervised by a Faculty member on a topic of common interest, including readings, discussions, papers. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 300+ FRE Linguistics/Literature/Second Language Learning course. Permission of Department.
